Issues.Title: Add a mechanism to assure that the Angularjs app loads first in hybrid application
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/upgrade


### Description
All you can find about the migration incrementally to new Angular has been mentioned [here](https://angular.io/guide/upgrade) and many examples across the web which all mention to a little application that you can load the Angularjs file by script tag inside index.html and then bootstrap the app. In case that you have a big application more than 500,000 lines of code this approach won't work in any way and loading a bundle of old angularjs app too. If the bundle be huge, there is no way you be sure the angularjs has been loaded first and then Angular ngUpgrade bootstrap the app.


### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be great that there be a mechanism that you be able to load first the angularjs or somehow tell the angular app to wait first for Angularjs and then load the angular app and bootstrap it.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I don't know if it is a good idea but In this case, I guess the only way is to change completely the building setup and customize it somehow by implementing Webpack instead of Angular-Cli (I'm still working on it) and build your app the way it will work.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add a mechanism to assure that the Angularjs app loads first in hybrid application " (#27844)

Issues.Title: Redirect to root url does not work when returning UrlTree from guard
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/router ### Is this a regression? No. ### Description I use a guard to protect a route. If the user is not allowed to access the route I'd like to redirect to the root url. I'm doing this by returning an UrlTree from the canActivate method. To get the UrlTree for the root url I'm calling router.parseUrl('/'). However when I navigate to the protected page the redirect to the root url does not happen. The protected page isn't displayed either and there are no errors in the console. If I change the guard to return router.parseUrl('/unauthorized') the redirect to the unauthorized page works as expected. I think this should also work for the root url. Am I missing something or is this a bug? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-issue-repro2-w72ytp](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-issue-repro2-w72ytp) ## üî• Exception or Error None ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
All packages are effected by the output of `ngcc`


### Description

After running `ngcc` via `node_modules/.bin/ivy-ngcc` certain Angular decorators are being retained, this is break production builds with Build Optimzer https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13261.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

- Run ngcc against a node_modules/@angular directory
- Open node_modules/@angular/platform-browser/esm5/src/browser.js
```ts
var BrowserModule_1;
BrowserModule = BrowserModule_1 = tslib_1.__decorate([
	NgModule({ providers: BROWSER_MODULE_PROVIDERS, exports: [CommonModule, ApplicationModule] }),
	tslib_1.__param(0, Optional()), tslib_1.__param(0, SkipSelf()), tslib_1.__param(0, Inject(BrowserModule_1)),
	tslib_1.__metadata("design:paramtypes", [Object])
], BrowserModule);
return BrowserModule;
```

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**
```
Node: 10.10.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 7.2.0-rc.0
```


**Anything else relevant?**
According to @IgorMinar, there should not be any Angular specific decorators after running `ngcc`.

Issues.Title: new behavior for global ErrorHandler and uncaught errors from promises
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Well I thought this was zone.js wrapping the errors, but I rolled zone back only zone and it didn't change. ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was 5.x ### Description Previously, unhandled errors from promises were handed to a custom error handler unchanged. But now, it seems the error is wrapped and you need to unwrap it to get the real error that's sitting on the "rejection" property of the error. The docs make no mention of this here https://angular.io/api/core/ErrorHandler and neither does any googling surprisingly. I noticed this only after upgrading from angular 5 to angular 7 and one of my e2e tests that relied on my general error handler started failing. The only workaround I found was to have something like this at the top of the error handler's handleError() method like this: ```typescript while(error.rejection) { error = error.rejection; } ``` but... 1. I'm quite sure there's a better way - now I have to type error as any 2. I'm not sure if there are any other situations that will require unwrapping (e.g. from observables?). Either way, if this was some kind of intentional feature, it's definitely a gotcha that I think should be mentioned (with the RIGHT way to handle it) in the doc link I pasted. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. follow the docs and implement a global error handler and try to handle unhandled requests uniformly - something like this: ```typescript @Injectable() export class SpiffyErrorHandlerService implements ErrorHandler { constructor(private injector: Injector, private snackBar: MatSnackBar) {} public handleError(error: Error) { if (error instanceof HttpErrorResponse) { if (error.status === 401) { this.snackBar.open( 'Oops. It looks like you tried to access a logged-in resource while logged out. Please log in again.', '', { duration: 3000 } ); } } } ``` 2. inject HttpClient 3. await this.http.get('/some-404-returning-url').toPromise(); ## üî• Exception or Error EXPECTED: error handler works, gets the HttpErrorResponse, and shows the snackbar ACTUAL: the HttpErrorResponse is on error.rejection instead of right on error. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Node: 10.14.2

Issues.Title: Docs unclear on withCredentials following RequestOptions deprecation
Issues.Body:
### Description

I have a [problem](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53925631/angular-cors-put-missing-authorization-header-after-options-preflight) with my Authorization header not being sent. I've been reading as much documentation as I can find, and [MDN's take](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Allow-Credentials) states that:

> For a CORS request with credentials, in order for browsers to expose the response to frontend JavaScript code, both the server (using the Access-Control-Allow-Credentials header) and the client (by setting the credentials mode for the XHR, Fetch, or Ajax request) must indicate that they‚Äôre opting in to including credentials.

So, how do I "set the credentials mode" for my XHR PUT request from Angular, if `withCredentials: true` is deprecated?

### What's the affected URL?**

https://angular.io/api/http/RequestOptions (deprecated), pointing to https://angular.io/guide/http which is lovely and shiny but doesn't mention anything about how to set the credentials mode.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Docs unclear on withCredentials following RequestOptions deprecation" (#27828)

Issues.Title: fix(bazel): ng_package creates invalid typings reexport on windows
Issues.Body:
Currently when building a package on Windows, the typings re-export for secondary entry-points is not valid TypeScript. Similarly the metadata and the "package.json" files use non-posix paths and cause inconsistency within the NPM package.

For example:

_package.json_
```
  "esm5": "./esm5\\core.js",
  "esm2015": "./esm2015\\core.js",
```

_testing.d.ts_ (of the `core` package)
```
export * from './testing\testing';
```

**Note**: A test for the typings re-export is already part of the `golden` testing of the `ng_package`. Though, the golden testing seems to not run at the moment. We should try getting it work on Windows, and re-enable it on the CI in the future.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(bazel): ng_package creates invalid typings reexport on windows" (#27827)

Issues.Title: Child canLoad executes before parent canActivate on child reload.
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
The issue is caused by package @angular/router

### Description
When using lazy loading with a canLoad guard, if we reload the page on the child (lazy loaded) route, the child canLoad gets called before the parent route canActivate.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-zhyqwj, click on loadChild then reload page and watch console, output is in this order: 
**ChildGuard canLoad
AppGuard canActivate
AppResolver resolve**

even though the order of the routes are like this:

`const routes: Routes = [
  {
    path: '',
    component: AppComponent,
    resolve: [AppResolver],
    children: [
      {
        path: '', canActivate: [AppGuard], children: [
          {
            path: 'child',
            loadChildren: 'app/child/child.module#ChildModule',
            canLoad: [ChildGuard]
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
];`

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**
7.0.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Child canLoad executes before parent canActivate on child reload." (#27826)

import * as i2 from "../../../../node_modules/@angular/router/router.ngfactory";

This appears to be happening when the module that is included in the project contains entryComponents.

We are expecting that this should point towards @angular/router in this specific case.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Clone https://github.com/mitsoe/compile-issue
npm install
npm run build
you can see the ngc output in the dist folder. this contains the relative paths to the node_modules of its parent.

Issues.Title: Angular CLI @7 Library Build path references
Issues.Body:
<!--
IF YOU DON'T FILL OUT THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION YOUR ISSUE MIGHT BE CLOSED WITHOUT INVESTIGATING
-->
### Bug Report or Feature Request (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ x] bug report -> please search issues before submitting
- [ ] feature request
```

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x ] build
- [ x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Versions
ng: 7.1.4
Node: 10.13.0
OS: Win 10 x64 

### Repro steps
1. Scaffold a new Angular CLI project with the @7 generator.
2. Generate a new Library using the subgenerator: **ng g library libraryname --prefix=xx**
3. Add a Typings file (**index.d.ts**) under the lib folder of the library
4. Add a global namespace declaration into the Typings file
5. Add a path reference to this Typings file 
6. Run the build command for the project: **ng build libraryname**
7. Open the dist folder and then the subfolder with the name of the library.
8. The index.d.ts Typings file will appear within the lib folder, but under the esm5 and esm2015 folders, the public_api.js files contain references to the Typings file which the path is invalid, as these are within a sub folder.

Alternativley, you can add the Typings file right next to the public_api.ts file and add the references, and the paths will still be incorrect.


### The log given by the failure
No Error on build, but on serve I recieve:
ERROR ReferenceError: atlas is not defined.

### Desired functionality
Although this is a Global Namespace inside the typings file, and the Intellisense on VS Code picks it up without having to add any new references in the main application for testing, upon serving the project to test the library, the project is not able to find the namespace.


### Mention any other details that might be useful
You can clone and run [this project](https://github.com/xavidram/AtlasTypingsIssue.git) to see the error.

Issues.Title: revert: fix(@ngtools/webpack): emit lazy routes errors on rebuilds
Issues.Body:
This reverts commit edb84b340ff996df2ca6a2aaf765304cc64fef3e

The team has decided to bring back the faster but potentially less accurate method of detecting lazy routes upon JIT rebuilds (first builds will always use the more complete Angular compiler method). Applications that do not have lazy routes within libraries and that only use direct string literals with loadChildren should not be affected by the potential of less accurate detection. Note that the function overload of loadChildren also does not apply to this situation.

For those projects where correctness of lazy route detection outweighs rebuild speed, please consider using AOT mode for development. AOT mode will also provide a full set of template errors as well which JIT mode is not capable of doing.

Fixes #13102
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "revert: fix(@ngtools/webpack): emit lazy routes errors on rebuilds" (#13309)

### Desired functionality

Support for `pnpm` as a `packageManager` option (along with `yarn`, etc). This will allow us to use ng commands which manipulate `package.json` (like `ng update`) in our repository which uses `pnpm`'s workspace features (so `npm install` won't work). Because `pnpm` generally provides the same commands as `npm` it should be just a matter of adding it to the schema and using the `pnpm` executable instead of the `npm` one when so configured.

Issues.Title: Bug(ngtools/webpack): elideImports transformer mistakenly treat jsxFactory as unused import
Issues.Body:
### Bug Report or Feature Request (mark with an `x`) ``` - [x] bug report -> please search issues before submitting - [ ] feature request ``` ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Versions ``` node --version v11.2.0 npm --version 6.5.0 ng --version _ _ ____ _ ___ / \ _ __ __ _ _ _| | __ _ _ __ / ___| | |_ _| / ‚ñ≥ \ | '_ \ / _` | | | | |/ _` | '__| | | | | | | / ___ \| | | | (_| | |_| | | (_| | | | |___| |___ | | /_/ \_\_| |_|\__, |\__,_|_|\__,_|_| \____|_____|___| |___/ Angular CLI: 7.1.4 Node: 11.2.0 OS: darwin x64 Angular: 7.1.4 ... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic ... router Package Version ----------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.11.4 @angular-devkit/build-angular 0.11.4 @angular-devkit/build-optimizer 0.11.4 @angular-devkit/build-webpack 0.11.4 @angular-devkit/core 7.1.4 @angular-devkit/schematics 7.1.4 @ngtools/webpack 7.1.4 @schematics/angular 7.1.4 @schematics/update 0.11.4 rxjs 6.3.3 typescript 3.1.6 webpack 4.23.1 ``` ### Repro steps Say that current `jsxFactory` being set to `createElement`, given an Angular `.tsx` file, like: ```typescript import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { createElement } from './render'; console.log(

123

); @Component({ selector: 'app-root', templateUrl: './app.component.html', styleUrls: ['./app.component.css'] }) export class AppComponent { title = 'ng-tmp-c'; } ``` When building with AOT, the `AngularCompilerPlugin` would apply [`removeDecorators`](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/0b7dd0e9c0a76b1f46feafa01104e5f0d3b4d8b6/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.ts#L849) transformer to the build process. As this Angular file contains some decorator (`@Component()` here), `removeDecorators` is activated and uses [`elideImports`](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/0b7dd0e9c0a76b1f46feafa01104e5f0d3b4d8b6/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/transformers/make_transform.ts#L47) transformer to remove unused decorator imports. Inside that `elideImports` transformer, it [records "all" the used imports](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/0b7dd0e9c0a76b1f46feafa01104e5f0d3b4d8b6/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/transformers/elide_imports.ts#L62-L64), but it doesn't deal with jsx node properly as not transformed yet, so that `jsxFactory` is not an identifier and not being recorded. Then the import being removed and results to a broken file: ```javascript // createElement becomes global variable here console.log(createElement("p", null, "123")); var AppComponent = /** @class */ (function () { function AppComponent() { this.title = 'ng-tmp-c'; } return AppComponent; }()); ``` ### The log given by the failure N/A ### Desired functionality Support `.tsx` in AOT like what in JIT. ### Mention any other details that might be useful Suggested labels: `type: bug/fix`, `effort1: easy`, `freq1: low`, `severity3: broken`, `workaround2: non-obvious`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Bug(ngtools/webpack): elideImports transformer mistakenly treat jsxFactory as unused import" (#13297)

Issues.Body:

* Serves the e2e app with Bazel

Issues.Title: Mat-menu keyboard accessibility breaks when mat-menu-item is hidden
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
When hidden item is used in mat-menu then focus should not go to that item.
If hidden field is used then while navigation it should skip that item and focus on next visible item.

#### What is the current behavior?

Currently if hidden item is used in mat-menu  then user need to press Down Arrow key two times to reach on next visible item

In below example user needs to press **DOWN ARROW** two time to reach on item4 from item2.
`
<mat-menu #menu="matMenu">
  <button mat-menu-item>Item 1</button>
  <button mat-menu-item>Item 2</button>
  <button mat-menu-item style="display:none">Item 3</button>
  <button mat-menu-item>Item 4</button>
  <button mat-menu-item>Item 5</button>
</mat-menu>
`
#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-mat-menu-accessibility-issue

Open above link and follow below steps
1. Enter on menu button
2. Observe behavior on item2 when you press DOWN ARROW key, you will find you need to press key two time to reach on item4 as item3 is hidden.
 


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7+

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Mat-menu keyboard accessibility breaks when mat-menu-item is hidden" (#14653)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): unable to move item into connected container by passing through another container
Issues.Body:
Fixes not being able to move an item from one container into another by passing it through an intermediate container that isn't connected to the final one. The issue comes from the fact that the way things are set up at the moment, the container from which the item started the sequence knows which containers it can go into, however all that knowledge is reset once the item enters into a different container. These changes rework the logic to have the individual containers know whether the item can enter into them and have the source container "ask" each of its siblings whether the item can enter.

Fixes #14645.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(drag-drop): unable to move item into connected container by passing through another container" (#14651)

Issues.Title: fix(focus-trap): apply aria-hidden to focus trap tab anchors
Issues.Body:
These anchors at the book ends of a FocusTrap'ed element have focus listeners that redirect focus
back to the element. However, some screen readers may access these focus traps without moving
programmatic focus, leaving the SR user wondering why an empty control lives on the page.  Android
TalkBack currently treats this as a stop with no announcement (because it has no content). Adding
the aria-hidden should prevent these from being accessed in SR contexts while preserving the core
functionality of redirecting focus when it's moved linearly (e.g., with tab).

cdk FocusTrap adds focus trap divs with tabindex=0 at the beginning and end of the trapped container to prevent focus from leaving when pressing tab or linearly navigating. When these elements are focused, a focus handler redirects the browser focus as to effectively cycle focus within an element. This works fine for e.g., OS X VoiceOver, which generally moves focus when navigating the page. However some screenreaders may routinely browse elements without moving focus. A notable example is TalkBack, which is one of Angular Material's supported environments https://github.com/angular/material2#browser-and-screen-reader-support. This is also true in some popular configurations of JAWS/NVDA.

Settings these to have aria-hidden=true will typically cause for SRs to ignore these when linearly navigating the page, if they're not already ignored.

I've tested a primitive version of this fix on TalkBack and it works well.

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-e9gqbr?file=app%2Fdialog-content-example.ts
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SN1chzTfvTs

I can imagine some rare edge cases where this could cause a regression in functionality. In cases where cdk FocusTrap is used but were relying on SRs to "see" the focus trap anchors and shift focus to them, so that the active focus handler would redirect focus, this may break things, and SRs may wrongly shift focus to a bad spot. However, doing it this way would have been extremely finicky in the first place. If you wanted SRs not to be able to escape the focus trap, you should have set aria-hidden on the rest of the page in the first place (MatDialog does this https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/d22f48c742c0bbdc971f79ea1261ec5c20d15a69/src/lib/dialog/dialog.ts#L345, and individual application code may wrap cdk Overlay to do this; it's a bit of a mystery to me why cdk Overlay or cdk FocusTrap doesn't do this itself, but that's a separate concern). Such a page would have been a pain for SRs in the first place since heading and landmark navigation, common SR navigation techniques, could easily have shifted focus to the underlying page anyway. These users should be encouraged to apply aria-hidden appropriately. That said, we have tested this on the following SRs on the latest versions and things appear to be no worse:

Android TalkBack - my fix should address the hidden SR stop
NVDA/JAWS with virtual cursor - similar fix, but virtual cursor configuration varies greatly among users; generally, the hidden tab stops aren't problematic
OS X VO - always ignored the empty tabindex=0 anchors anyway

Internal bug reference b/122041252.

Issues.Title: build: unable to render individual examples in demo app
Issues.Body: Seems like something that was broken by #14522 by accident. Since the custom component is compiled inside the example list, we can't use individual examples anymore which breaks the ripple demo. These changes move the compilation into the `example` and simplify the setup a little bit.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: unable to render individual examples in demo app" (#14643)

Issues.Title: build: bazel repository changes not cached on circleci
Issues.Body:
Currently if we update the Bazel `WORKSPACE` and some external repositories have changed, CircleCI won't be able to cache the bazel repositories because the cache-key has not changed and saving will be skipped. We should make sure that the Bazel repositories will be cached properly because otherwise this can cause a significant slow-down with Bazel managed deps.

Additionally we no longer store the cache based on the current `branch` because that means that caching does not always work for pull requests. Since the caching only depends on two inputs (yarn.lock and WORKSPACE), it's safe to just remove the branch from the cache key.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: bazel repository changes not cached on circleci" (#14642)

Issues.Title: fix(tabs): use buttons for paginator
Issues.Body: Uses `button` elements, rather than styled `div`-s for the paginator buttons. This has the advantage of being more semantic and accessible, if we decided to make them focusable, and it stops calling the click listeners when the button is disabled (currently we do some expensive checks in them when we don't have to).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(tabs): use buttons for paginator" (#14640)

Issues.Title: fix(scrolling): virtual list not updating when source array is mutated
Issues.Body:
When an array is passed to `cdkVirtualFor`, it falls back to creating an `ArrayDataSource` which won't emit if the array has changed. Since the intention of the `cdkVirtualFor` is to be (more or less) a drop-in alternative for `ngFor`, it is expected that it'll update if the data has changed. These changes add a new type of data source that will allow us to detect changes on the data and to update the view.

**Note:** I went with adding a new type of data source, rather than using the iterable differ directly, because it would've meant having to maintain two different code paths inside the directive. Furthermore, I can see this being useful in `cdk/tree` and `cdk/table` as well.

Fixes #14635.
Fixes #14501.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(scrolling): virtual list not updating when source array is mutated" (#14639)

Issues.Title: Datepicker out of viewport
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Datepicker should be inside of the viewport and be fully rendered

#### What is the current behavior?
Sometimes it's out of viewport so that user is unable to do anything. Also it's impossible to scroll to that part that is "invisible". Moreover, sometimes datepicker is in viewport, however it's back rendered till last line and 31 Dec is out of datepicker.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
It could be reproduced in any project that uses datepicker. The idea is to make datepicker field from the end of viewport/page on about 4/5 of datepicker calendar size. Thus, we get this 1/5 out of available space.

To reproduce the second screenshot you will need to make your window height as narrow as about 300px


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
"@angular/core": "^6.1.10"
"@angular/material": "^7.2.0"
"typescript": "~2.9.2"
MacOS, Ubuntu
Chrome

#### Is there anything else we should know?
![screen shot 2018-12-25 at 10 43 05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22374911/50418046-1a0da680-0832-11e9-8865-5aa9b303c32b.png)
It's bottom of the page in Chrome on macOS.
The same behaviour was observed in Chrome on Ubuntu.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22374911/50418310-61486700-0833-11e9-85bd-a41c507c2a05.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Datepicker out of viewport" (#14631)
